A carbon tax is a form of carbon pricing where a fee is imposed on the carbon content of fossil fuels. It is designed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by making fossil fuels more expensive and encouraging the use of cleaner alternatives.
relations.Subject: carbon tax

relations.Description: Cap and trade is a market-based approach to carbon pricing. It sets a limit (cap) on the total amount of greenhouse gas emissions allowed and allows companies to buy and sell emission allowances. This creates a financial incentive for companies to reduce their emissions.
relations.Subject: cap and trade

relations.Description: Emissions trading is another form of market-based carbon pricing. It allows companies to buy and sell emission permits or credits. Companies that can reduce emissions at a lower cost can sell their excess permits to companies that face higher costs.
relations.Subject: emissions trading

relations.Description: Offsets are a mechanism used in carbon pricing to compensate for emissions by investing in projects that reduce or remove greenhouse gas emissions. These projects can include reforestation, renewable energy, or energy efficiency initiatives.
relations.Subject: offsets

relations.Description: Revenue recycling refers to the use of the revenue generated from carbon pricing mechanisms. It can be used to fund renewable energy projects, support low-income households, or invest in climate adaptation and mitigation measures.
relations.Subject: revenue recycling
